resource.chars:
Obs:2. When the Plate of Aire by turning the Prisms at 
their comon Axis became So little inclined to the incident rays, the 
Some of them began to be transmitted, there arose in it many Slen[der?]
Arcs of colours wch at first were shaped 
almost like the conchoid as you See them
here delineated. And by continueing the 
motion of the Prisms, these Arcs increased 
& bended more & more about ye said transparent Spott, till they [text?]
compleated into circles or Ringes incompassing it, & afterwards continu[ed?]
grew more & more contracted.
These Arcs at their first appearance were of a violet and 
blew colour and between them were white Arcs of Circles wch 
presently became a little tinged in their inward Limbs with re[d]
& yellow, & to their Outward limbs the blew was adjacent.
So that the Order of these colours from the Centrall darke 
Spott, was at that time white, Blew, Violet, Black, Redd,
Orange, Yellow, white Blew, Violet, &c But the yellow &
Red were much fainter then the Blew and violet.
The motion of the Prisms about their Axis being 
continued these colours contracted more and more, shrinking 
towards the whiteness on either Side of it, untill they 
totally vanished into it; And then the Circles in those parts 
appeared black and white, without any other colours -
intermixed, But by further moving the Prisms about 
the Colours againe [e]merged out of the whitenesse, the violet and 
Blew at its inward limb, and at its Outward Limb the red and 
yellow, So that now their Order from the Centrall Spott was 
white, Yellow, Redd: Black, Violet,  Blew, White, Yellow, Red &
contrary to what it was before.
Obs:3. When the Rings or Some parts appeared onely 
Black & white, they were very distinct and well defined, and 
their Blacknesse Seemed as intense as that of the Centrall Spott,
Also in the Borders of these Rings where the colours began 
to emerge out of the whiteness, they were pretty distinct,
wch made them visible to a very great multitude. I haue 
Somtimes Numbred aboue Thirty Successions (Reckoning 
every black & white ring for one Succession) and Seen more 
of them, wch by reason of their Smallness I could not number 
But in other Positions of the Prisms at wch the Rings -
appeared of many colours, I could not distinguish aboue 
8 or 9 of them, & the exteriour of those as were confused 
and dilute.
In these two Observac[i]ons to see the Rings distinct &
without any other colour but black & white, I found it 
necessary
